content: For these messages that are getting marked as spam, do you have contact entries in your address book(s) for the senders?
creator: wsmwk

content:
Also, do the message have the spam flame icon, or no?

In the example I am posting here (from a Mac), two message have the flame and two do not.
creator: wsmwk

content: none of them are marked with the flame icon (i've literally never seen anything marked with the flame icon) and about a dozen of them are in my contact list. I've marked as not junk over and over but they still end up in the spam folder.
creator: threenorns

content: Messages that do not have the flame icon would not have put in the spam folder by Thunderbird. (unless you created a filter to do that)
creator: wsmwk

content:
The only filters i've created are the ones i created to try and catch them and put them back in my inbox.

i've never, not even once, seen anything marked with a flame icon.

I just checked now: not a single one of them is marked with a flame, not even the ones i specifically marked "spam". just on the first screenshot, there's 3 clients, all of whom i've lost for non-response, all of whom i was emailing on the regular up to about 2wks ago.

bottom line: i'm in the process of transferring to outlook. it has its issues but at least they're predictable and at least i can get proper customer support.
creator: threenorns

content: Sorry, I'm not seeing a screen shot.
creator: wsmwk

content: Also, creating a filter and having them end up in the spam folder again is further suggests that Thunderbird isn't doing this. It's probably your mail provider, whom you have not identified.

content:
Mac native AB is read only.

But AIUI you can set your mac AB to save to icloud, and then from Thunderbird there access it as carddav. https://danielbrinneman.com/2022/12/12/sync-icloud-contacts-with-mozilla-thunderbird/
creator: wsmwk

content: Thunderbird uses its own addressbook. There may be such an addon, but I am not aware of it.

content: The 2GB was only a guideline. We're pleased your import went well.
creator: davidsk

content: That message usually appears when all the information is not listed, causing Thunderbird to attempt to locate the information on its own. I suggest you click the 'manual' option and key in all the info. To ensure the basics are found, I suggest omitting the password.
creator: davidsk

content:
Here is a link to the many varieties of version 91, a stable and reliable version, minus new features of past two years. The link is for all versions. For example, if you use Windows on a 64-bit PC, click the win64 directory, then click your preferred language and then click the exe version to download. 

 https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/91.13.1/
creator: davidsk

content:
The settings are correct, but you must create a secure mail key and use it in TB in place of the account password.

https://www.att.com/support/article/dsl-high-speed/KM1010523/
creator: sfhowes

content:
The incoming and outgoing gmail servers should use OAuth2 authentication. The outgoing mycci.net port should be 465 with SSL/TLS security.

https://www.consolidated.com/support/email-settings-user-guides/ht-email-user-guides/email-server-settings

Set each account to send on an smtp server with matching User Name (email address).

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593
creator: sfhowes

content: TB 115 supports CardDAV without add-ons: in Address Book, click New Address Book, Add CardDAV Address Book, enter your gmail address, complete the OAuth authentication with the account password, add Google Contacts as a new address book.
creator: sfhowes
